awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Impact of the Miraflores El Niño Flood on the Chiribaya of Far Southern Peru
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to study the impact of a coastal drought and a subsequent flood caused by the climatic anomaly known as ENSO (El Niño Southern Oscillation) in a coastal region. This project reconstructs both the cultural and environmental history at a coastal archaeological site and then place the site within the broader archaeological history of the region. In this region a prolonged drought followed by catastrophic flooding caused the abandonment and reduction of coastal populations. To date, research on this region has focused on societal collapse due to environmental change. In contrast, this project acknowledges the challenges associated with climatic changes, while also emphasizing the ingenuity of people in unpredictable landscapes. Archaeology is particularly well placed to continue research on this drought and flood event, while putting it within the broader context of cultural adaptation and change. The project provides localized environmental data on what coastal peoples experienced over a ca. 300 year period. Additionally, it adds to the archaeological knowledge of landscape use and reuse in an area with an extended period of human history. The project focuses on professionalization and training of members of an international research team that will further disseminate their research on these topics.

This project focuses on a period of major environmental and cultural changes. Though research has been done at other sites to understand the impact of the coastal drought and flood, this project is the first regional scale analysis of this period of regional  prehistory. Specifically, the research addresses two main questions: How did coastal peoples adapt to unpredictable climate conditions? And what was the collective impact of the drought and El Niño floods on the coast? To answer these questions the research team uses a combination of archaeological, geological, and biological research methods. The researcher leads a team of archaeologists, geoarchaeologists, and palynologists (pollen analysts) to conduct archaeological excavations, artifact analysis, sediment sampling and analysis, and pollen sampling and analysis. These interdisciplinary researchers address the convergence of environmental and human forces to understand agricultural and irrigational adaptations that allowed people to be resilient following these climate disasters. This team will develop a local record of environmental change that will be accessible to others conducting climate change research in multiple arid environments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
"The Impact of the Miraflores El Nino Flood on the Chiribaya of Far Southern Peru" doctoral research project studied the impact of a major drought and a subsequent severe flood (the Miraflores event) that occurred in the archaeological record between ~1100-1470 CE on the far southern coast of Peru. This flood was the result of a climatic anomaly known as ENSO (El Nino Southern Oscillation), which still impacts the Peruvian coast today. During this period, the Chiribaya, a coastal polity, inhabited this region. The convergence of the coastal drought and the El Nino flood ultimately led to the collapse of the Chiribaya polity and the abandonment of many coastal settlements.

To study this period of dramatic climatic events, the PIs focused on the cultural and environmental history of Tacahuay Tambo (a coastal archaeological site). While most research to date on this region focused on societal collapse due to environmental change, this project instead emphasized the ingenuity of people in unpredictable landscapes. Specifically, this research aimed to answer two main questions: How did coastal peoples adapt to unpredictable climate conditions? And what was the collective impact of the drought and El Nino floods on the coast? The grant provided by the National Science Foundation specifically funded the analysis of radiocarbon and pollen samples collected from Tacahuay Tambo. The radiocarbon samples were successful at creating a local chronology of cultural and flood events for the site, while the pollen samples created a proxy for cultivation and environmental changes that were occurring at the site during this period of convergent catastrophes.

During the 2022 field season, 34 radiocarbon samples were analyzed to produce a time line of events at Tacahuay Tambo. The analysis of 22 of these samples was funded by this NSF grant. The samples were chosen based upon their stratigraphic location, including depth (collected below disturbed topsoil) and context (found within a level with ceramics, faunal, lithic material etc. characteristic of different cultural periods). Ultimately, we found that the site's main agricultural fields were in use between 1000 BCE and 1900s CE and the northern fields were in use between 1100 BCE and 500 CE. We were also able to date evidence that Tacahuay Tambo was in fact in use both before and after the Miraflores flood, suggesting that the local population was resilient following both the coastal drought and the major flood event. Unlike many of the other Chiribaya sites on the far southern coast of Peru, the people at Tacahuay Tambo were successful at managing their local resources, despite major environmental change, as well as at mitigating flood damage.

Fifteen pollen and sediment samples from agricultural areas were taken by palynologists from the Universidad Peruana Cayetano Heredia in Lima, Peru and the PIs. This paleoenvironmental data was essential for understanding the cultivation of crops during the LIP and the changing environment at Tacahuay Tambo. NSF specifically supported the analysis of seven of these samples. These results provided evidence of flowering plants that could indicate periods of wet and dry climate and domesticated plants. The domesticated plants include corn, cereal plants, and quinoa.  

I ultimately conclude that the people of Tacahuay were successful at navigating the challenges associated with this dynamic landscape because of the legacy of use and re-use of the site through time. People inhabited the site area between 1000 BCE and 500 CE. During that period, they had a diverse resource collection strategy that allowed them to live in an arid environment prone to natural disasters. Then, Chiribaya peoples settled at this site around 1000 CE, further cultivated this landscape for agricultural purposes and remained resilient following the LIP convergent catastrophes. The data generated for this project provides localized environmental data on what coastal peoples experienced from roughly 1100-1470 CE. Additionally, the PIs added to the archaeological knowledge of landscape use and reuse in an area with 12,000 years of human history. The results of this research are currently being prepared for publication. The PIs intend to submit three different published articles to open access journals. One of those publications will be a journal that is published in both English and Spanish, which will reach a broader audience in both the US and the Andes.
